an5.30:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena icchānaṅgalaṃ nāma kosalānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
an5.30:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Icchānaṅgala.

an5.30:1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
an5.30:1.3.eng: He stayed in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.

an5.30:1.4.eng: The brahmins and householders of Icchānaṅgala heard:

an5.30:1.5.pli: “samaṇo khalu bho gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito icchānaṅgalaṃ anuppatto; icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
an5.30:1.5.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Icchānaṅgala. He is staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.

an5.30:1.6.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

an5.30:1.7.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi, satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti’.
an5.30:1.7.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an5.30:1.8.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
an5.30:1.8.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

an5.30:1.9.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
an5.30:1.9.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an5.30:1.10.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī”ti.
an5.30:1.10.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

an5.30:1.11.pli: Atha kho icchānaṅgalakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tassā rattiyā accayena pahūtaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ ādāya yena icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bahidvārakoṭṭhake aṭṭhaṃsu uccāsaddamahāsaddā.
an5.30:1.11.eng: Then, when the night had passed, they took many fresh and cooked foods and went to the forest near Icchānaṅgala, where they stood outside the gates making a colossal racket.

an5.30:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nāgito bhagavato upaṭṭhāko hoti.
an5.30:2.1.eng: Now, at that time Venerable Nāgita was the Buddha’s attendant.

an5.30:2.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nāgitaṃ āmantesi:
an5.30:2.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to Nāgita,

an5.30:2.3.pli: “ke pana kho, nāgita, uccāsaddamahāsaddā, kevaṭṭā maññe macchavilope”ti?
an5.30:2.3.eng: “Nāgita, who’s making that colossal racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”

an5.30:2.4.pli: “Ete, bhante, icchānaṅgalakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā pahūtaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ ādāya bahidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhitā bhagavantaññeva uddissa bhikkhusaṅghañcā”ti.
an5.30:2.4.eng: “Sir, it’s these brahmins and householders of Icchānaṅgala. They’ve brought many fresh and cooked foods, and they’re standing outside the gates wanting to offer it specially to the Buddha and the mendicant Saṅgha.”

an5.30:2.5.pli: “Māhaṃ, nāgita, yasena samāgamaṃ, mā ca mayā yaso.
an5.30:2.5.eng: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.

an5.30:2.6.pli: Yo kho, nāgita, nayimassa nekkhammasukhassa pavivekasukhassa upasamasukhassa sambodhasukhassa nikāmalābhī assa akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, yassāhaṃ nekkhammasukhassa pavivekasukhassa upasamasukhassa sambodhasukhassa nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
an5.30:2.6.eng: There are those who can’t get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can.

an5.30:2.7.pli: So taṃ mīḷhasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ lābhasakkārasilokasukhaṃ sādiyeyyā”ti.
an5.30:2.7.eng: Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.”

an5.30:3.1.eng: “Sir, may the Blessed One please relent now! May the Holy One relent!

an5.30:3.2.eng: Now is the time for the Buddha to relent.

an5.30:3.3.pli: Yena yeneva dāni bhagavā gamissati taṃninnāva gamissanti brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
an5.30:3.3.eng: Wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders, and people of town and country will incline the same way.

an5.30:3.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, thullaphusitake deve vassante yathāninnaṃ udakāni pavattanti;
an5.30:3.4.eng: It’s like when the heavens rain heavily and the water flows downhill.

an5.30:3.5.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhante, yena yeneva dāni bhagavā gamissati, taṃninnāva gamissanti brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
an5.30:3.5.eng: In the same way, wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders, and people of town and country will incline the same way.

an5.30:3.7.eng: Because of the Buddha’s ethics and wisdom.”

an5.30:4.1.pli: “Māhaṃ, nāgita, yasena samāgamaṃ, mā ca mayā yaso.
an5.30:4.1.eng: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.

an5.30:4.2.pli: Yo kho, nāgita, nayimassa nekkhammasukhassa pavivekasukhassa upasamasukhassa sambodhasukhassa nikāmalābhī assa akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, yassāhaṃ nekkhammasukhassa pavivekasukhassa upasamasukhassa sambodhasukhassa nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
an5.30:4.2.eng: There are those who can’t get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can.

an5.30:4.3.pli: So taṃ mīḷhasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ lābhasakkārasilokasukhaṃ sādiyeyya.
an5.30:4.3.eng: Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.

an5.30:4.4.eng: What you eat, drink, chew, and taste ends up as excrement and urine.

an5.30:4.6.pli: Piyānaṃ kho, nāgita, vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā—
an5.30:4.6.eng: When loved ones decay and perish, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise.

an5.30:4.8.pli: Asubhanimittānuyogaṃ anuyuttassa kho, nāgita, subhanimitte pāṭikulyatā saṇṭhāti—
an5.30:4.8.eng: When you pursue meditation on the feature of ugliness, revulsion at the feature of beauty becomes stabilized.

an5.30:4.10.pli: Chasu kho, nāgita, phassāyatanesu aniccānupassino viharato phasse pāṭikulyatā saṇṭhāti—
an5.30:4.10.eng: When you meditate observing impermanence in the six fields of contact, revulsion at contact becomes stabilized.

an5.30:4.12.pli: Pañcasu kho, nāgita, upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino viharato upādāne pāṭikulyatā saṇṭhāti—
an5.30:4.12.eng: When you meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates, revulsion at grasping becomes stabilized.

an5.303:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, five things should be developed.

an5.303:1.3.pli: Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā—
an5.303:1.3.eng: The perceptions of ugliness, death, drawbacks, repulsiveness of food, and dissatisfaction with the whole world.

an5.303:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an5.303:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these five things should be developed.”

an5.304:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, five things should be developed.

an5.304:1.3.pli: Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā—
an5.304:1.3.eng: The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, death, repulsiveness of food, and dissatisfaction with the whole world.

an5.304:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an5.304:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these five things should be developed.”

an5.305:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, five things should be developed.

an5.305:1.3.pli: Aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā—
an5.305:1.3.eng: The perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in impermanence, the perception of not-self in suffering, the perception of giving up, and the perception of fading away.

an5.305:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an5.305:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these five things should be developed.”

an5.306:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, five things should be developed.

an5.306:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an5.306:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an5.306:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these five things should be developed.”

an5.307:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, five things should be developed.

an5.307:1.3.eng: The powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an5.307:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an5.307:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these five things should be developed.”

an5.308-1152:1.1.pli: “Rāgassa, bhikkhave, pariññāya … parikkhayāya … pahānāya … khayāya … vayāya … virāgāya … nirodhāya … cāgāya … paṭinissaggāya pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an5.308-1152:1.1.eng: “For the complete understanding … finishing … giving up … ending … vanishing … fading away … cessation … giving away … letting go of greed, five things should be developed.”

an5.308-1152:1.2.pli: Dosassa … mohassa … kodhassa … upanāhassa … makkhassa … paḷāsassa … issāya … macchariyassa … māyāya … sāṭheyyassa … thambhassa … sārambhassa … mānassa … atimānassa … madassa … pamādassa abhiññāya … pariññāya … parikkhayāya … pahānāya … khayāya … vayāya … virāgāya … nirodhāya … cāgāya … paṭinissaggāya pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an5.308-1152:1.2.eng: “Of hate … delusion … anger … acrimony … disdain … contempt … jealousy … stinginess … deceit … deviousness … obstinacy … aggression … conceit … arrogance … vanity … negligence … for insight … complete understanding … finishing … giving up … ending … vanishing … fading away … cessation … giving away … letting go … five things should be developed.

an5.308-1152:2.2.eng: The powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an5.308-1152:2.3.pli: pamādassa, bhikkhave, paṭinissaggāya ime pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an5.308-1152:2.3.eng: For the letting go of negligence, these five things should be developed.”

an5.308-1152:4.13.eng: The Book of the Fives is finished.

an5.31:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an5.31:1.2.pli: Atha kho sumanā rājakumārī pañcahi rathasatehi pañcahi rājakumārisatehi parivutā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho sumanā rājakumārī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.31:1.2.eng: Then Princess Sumanā, escorted by five hundred chariots and five hundred royal maidens, went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an5.31:2.1.pli: “Idhassu, bhante, bhagavato dve sāvakā samasaddhā samasīlā samapaññā—
an5.31:2.1.eng: “Sir, suppose there were two disciples equal in faith, ethics, and wisdom.

an5.31:2.2.eng: One is a giver, one is not.

an5.31:2.3.pli: Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyyuṃ.
an5.31:2.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.31:2.4.pli: Devabhūtānaṃ pana nesaṃ, bhante, siyā viseso, siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?
an5.31:2.4.eng: When they have become gods, would there be any distinction or difference between them?”

an5.31:3.1.eng: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.

an5.31:3.2.pli: “yo so, sumane, dāyako so amuṃ adāyakaṃ devabhūto samāno pañcahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an5.31:3.2.eng: “As a god, the one who was a giver surpasses the other in five respects:

an5.31:3.3.pli: dibbena āyunā, dibbena vaṇṇena, dibbena sukhena, dibbena yasena, dibbena ādhipateyyena.
an5.31:3.3.eng: heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, and sovereignty.

an5.31:3.4.pli: Yo so, sumane, dāyako so amuṃ adāyakaṃ devabhūto samāno imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti”.
an5.31:3.4.eng: As a god, the one who was a giver surpasses the other in these five respects.”

an5.31:4.1.pli: “Sace pana te, bhante, tato cutā itthattaṃ āgacchanti, manussabhūtānaṃ pana nesaṃ, bhante, siyā viseso, siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?
an5.31:4.1.eng: “But sir, if they pass away from there and come back to this place as human beings, would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”

an5.31:4.2.eng: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.

an5.31:4.3.pli: “yo so, sumane, dāyako so amuṃ adāyakaṃ manussabhūto samāno pañcahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an5.31:4.3.eng: “As a human being, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in five respects:

an5.31:4.4.pli: mānusakena āyunā, mānusakena vaṇṇena, mānusakena sukhena, mānusakena yasena, mānusakena ādhipateyyena.
an5.31:4.4.eng: human lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, and sovereignty.

an5.31:4.5.pli: Yo so, sumane, dāyako so amuṃ adāyakaṃ manussabhūto samāno imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti”.
an5.31:4.5.eng: As a human being, the one who was a giver surpasses the other in these five respects.”

an5.31:5.1.pli: “Sace pana te, bhante, ubho agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, pabbajitānaṃ pana nesaṃ, bhante, siyā viseso, siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?
an5.31:5.1.eng: “But sir, if they both go forth from the lay life to homelessness, would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”

an5.31:5.2.eng: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.

an5.31:5.3.pli: “yo so, sumane, dāyako so amuṃ adāyakaṃ pabbajito samāno pañcahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an5.31:5.3.eng: “As a renunciate, the one who was a giver surpasses the other in five respects.

an5.31:5.4.pli: yācitova bahulaṃ cīvaraṃ paribhuñjati appaṃ ayācito, yācitova bahulaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjati appaṃ ayācito, yācitova bahulaṃ senāsanaṃ paribhuñjati appaṃ ayācito, yācitova bahulaṃ gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ paribhuñjati appaṃ ayācito.
an5.31:5.4.eng: They usually use only what they’ve been invited to accept—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—rarely using them without invitation.

an5.31:5.5.pli: Yehi kho pana sabrahmacārīhi saddhiṃ viharati tyassa manāpeneva bahulaṃ kāyakammena samudācaranti appaṃ amanāpena, manāpeneva bahulaṃ vacīkammena samudācaranti appaṃ amanāpena, manāpeneva bahulaṃ manokammena samudācaranti appaṃ amanāpena, manāpaṃyeva bahulaṃ upahāraṃ upaharanti appaṃ amanāpaṃ.
an5.31:5.5.eng: When living with other spiritual practitioners, they usually find themselves treated agreeably by them by way of body, speech, and mind, and rarely disagreeably. And they are usually presented with agreeable things by them, rarely with disagreeable ones.

an5.31:5.6.pli: Yo so, sumane, dāyako so amuṃ adāyakaṃ pabbajito samāno imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhātī”ti.
an5.31:5.6.eng: As a renunciate, the one who was a giver surpasses the other in these five respects.”

an5.31:6.1.pli: “Sace pana te, bhante, ubho arahattaṃ pāpuṇanti, arahattappattānaṃ pana nesaṃ, bhante, siyā viseso, siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?
an5.31:6.1.eng: “But sir, if they both attain perfection, as perfected ones would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”

an5.31:6.2.pli: “Ettha kho panesāhaṃ, sumane, na kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ vadāmi, yadidaṃ vimuttiyā vimuttin”ti.
an5.31:6.2.eng: “In that case, I say there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.”

an5.31:7.2.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhante, alameva dānāni dātuṃ alaṃ puññāni kātuṃ;
an5.31:7.2.eng: This is quite enough to justify giving gifts and making merit.

an5.31:7.3.pli: yatra hi nāma devabhūtassāpi upakārāni puññāni, manussabhūtassāpi upakārāni puññāni, pabbajitassāpi upakārāni puññānī”ti.
an5.31:7.3.eng: For merit is helpful for those who have become gods, human beings, and renunciates.”

an5.31:7.5.pli: Alañhi, sumane, dānāni dātuṃ alaṃ puññāni kātuṃ.
an5.31:7.5.eng: It’s quite enough to justify giving gifts and making merit.

an5.31:7.6.pli: Devabhūtassāpi upakārāni puññāni, manussabhūtassāpi upakārāni puññāni, pabbajitassāpi upakārāni puññānī”ti.
an5.31:7.6.eng: For merit is helpful for those who have become gods, human beings, and renunciates.”

an5.31:8.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an5.31:8.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
an5.31:8.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

an5.31:9.2.eng: journeying across the dimension of space;

an5.31:11.2.eng: its hundred peaks wreathed in lightning,

an5.31:11.3.eng: pours down over the rich earth,

an5.31:12.1.eng: Even so, an astute person accomplished in vision,

an5.31:12.2.eng: a disciple of the fully awakened Buddha,

an5.31:13.4.eng: they depart to rejoice in heaven.”

an5.32:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
an5.32:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

an5.32:1.2.pli: Atha kho cundī rājakumārī pañcahi rathasatehi pañcahi ca kumārisatehi parivutā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho cundī rājakumārī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.32:1.2.eng: Then Princess Cundī, escorted by five hundred chariots and five hundred royal maidens, went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an5.32:2.1.pli: “Amhākaṃ, bhante, bhātā cundo nāma rājakumāro, so evamāha:
an5.32:2.1.eng: “Sir, my brother, Prince Cunda, says this:

an5.32:2.2.pli: ‘yadeva so hoti itthī vā puriso vā buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gato, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gato, pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, adinnādānā paṭivirato, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato, musāvādā paṭivirato, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃyeva upapajjati, no duggatin’ti.
an5.32:2.2.eng: ‘Take a woman or man who goes for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants. Only then do they get reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when their body breaks up, after death.’

an5.32:2.3.eng: And so I ask the Buddha:

an5.32:2.4.pli: ‘kathaṃrūpe kho, bhante, satthari pasanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃyeva upapajjati, no duggatiṃ?
an5.32:2.4.eng: Sir, what kind of teacher should you have confidence in so as to be reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when the body breaks up, after death?

an5.32:2.5.pli: Kathaṃrūpe dhamme pasanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃyeva upapajjati, no duggatiṃ?
an5.32:2.5.eng: Sir, what kind of teaching should you have confidence in so as to be reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when the body breaks up, after death?

an5.32:2.6.pli: Kathaṃrūpe saṅghe pasanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃyeva upapajjati, no duggatiṃ?
an5.32:2.6.eng: Sir, what kind of Saṅgha should you have confidence in so as to be reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when the body breaks up, after death?

an5.32:2.7.pli: Kathaṃrūpesu sīlesu paripūrakārī kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃyeva upapajjati, no duggatin’”ti?
an5.32:2.7.eng: Sir, what kind of ethics should you fulfill so as to be reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when the body breaks up, after death?”

an5.32:3.1.pli: “Yāvatā, cundi, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā rūpino vā arūpino vā saññino vā asaññino vā nevasaññināsaññino vā, tathāgato tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho.
an5.32:3.1.eng: “Cundī, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.

an5.32:3.2.pli: Ye kho, cundi, buddhe pasannā, agge te pasannā.
an5.32:3.2.eng: Those who have confidence in the Buddha have confidence in the best.

an5.32:3.3.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an5.32:3.3.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an5.32:4.1.pli: Yāvatā, cundi, dhammā saṅkhatā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati.
an5.32:4.1.eng: The noble eightfold path is said to be the best of all conditioned things.

an5.32:4.2.pli: Ye, cundi, ariye aṭṭhaṅgike magge pasannā, agge te pasannā, agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an5.32:4.2.eng: Those who have confidence in the noble eightfold path have confidence in the best. Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an5.32:5.1.pli: Yāvatā, cundi, dhammā saṅkhatā vā asaṅkhatā vā, virāgo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—
an5.32:5.1.eng: Fading away is said to be the best of all things whether conditioned or unconditioned.

an5.32:5.2.pli: madanimmadano pipāsavinayo ālayasamugghāto vaṭṭupacchedo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
an5.32:5.2.eng: That is, the quelling of vanity, the removing of thirst, the uprooting of clinging, the breaking of the round, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.

an5.32:5.3.pli: Ye kho, cundi, virāge dhamme pasannā, agge te pasannā.
an5.32:5.3.eng: Those who have confidence in the teaching of fading away have confidence in the best.

an5.32:5.4.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an5.32:5.4.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an5.32:6.1.pli: Yāvatā, cundi, saṅghā vā gaṇā vā, tathāgatasāvakasaṅgho tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—
an5.32:6.1.eng: The Saṅgha of the Realized One’s disciples is said to be the best of all communities and groups.

an5.32:6.2.pli: cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā, esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an5.32:6.2.eng: It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an5.32:6.3.pli: Ye kho, cundi, saṅghe pasannā, agge te pasannā.
an5.32:6.3.eng: Those who have confidence in the Saṅgha have confidence in the best.

an5.32:6.4.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an5.32:6.4.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an5.32:7.1.pli: Yāvatā, cundi, sīlāni, ariyakantāni sīlāni tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—
an5.32:7.1.eng: The ethical conduct loved by the noble ones is said to be the best of all ethics.

an5.32:7.2.pli: akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni.
an5.32:7.2.eng: It is intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

an5.32:7.3.pli: Ye kho, cundi, ariyakantesu sīlesu paripūrakārino, agge te paripūrakārino.
an5.32:7.3.eng: Those who fulfill the ethics loved by the noble ones fulfill the best.

an5.32:7.4.pli: Agge kho pana paripūrakārīnaṃ aggo vipāko hotīti.
an5.32:7.4.eng: Fulfilling the best, the result is the best.

an5.32:8.1.eng: For those who, knowing the best teaching,

an5.32:8.2.eng: base their confidence on the best—

an5.32:8.3.eng: confident in the best Awakened One,

an5.32:8.4.eng: supremely worthy of a religious donation;

an5.32:9.2.eng: the bliss of fading and stilling;

an5.32:11.1.eng: An intelligent person gives to the best,

an5.32:11.3.eng: When they become a god or human,

an5.32:11.4.eng: they rejoice at reaching the best.”
